1_fundamentals_of_the_idea.summary: Develop a high-fidelity driver-in-the-loop simulation system to train FSAE drivers, reduce cone penalties, and improve dynamic event performance.
core_principles: FSAE dynamic events penalize cone hits with +20 seconds each, making precision more important than pure speed.
Real car testing is limited by cost, safety, logistics, and track availability.
A realistic simulator allows unlimited safe practice and predictive feedback.
Telemetry-driven models ensure the simulator reflects actual NUS vehicle behavior.
1_fundamentals_of_the_idea.goal: Create a simulation ecosystem where drivers improve steering precision, braking consistency, and racing line discipline through structured, measurable training.

vehicle_physics_model.description: A validated digital twin using real telemetry (mass distribution, suspension geometry, tire curves, braking deceleration).

software: Cone-avoidance logic with real FSAE penalties

steps: System collects driving data (steering, braking, line).
Analytics compare driver performance with optimal metrics.
Simulator provides targeted corrections (e.g., brake earlier by 3m).

competitive_benefits: Significantly reduces cone penalties (+20s each), the most common cause of lost points in dynamic events.
Improves driver consistency, enabling faster and safer real-world performance.
Allows training for complex autocross maneuvers that cannot always be done in real life.
team_improvements: Creates a structured, data-driven driver development program.
Reduces car wear and testing costs by shifting early training to simulation.
Gives new team members a way to contribute via software, simulation, and analytics.
long_term_value: Establishes NUS Racing as a data- and simulation-driven team.
Supports future autonomous/DV research through validated vehicle models.
Provides valuable skills in control systems, simulation, and driver modeling.

physical_components: Steering wheel mount or cockpit replica (simple welded steel frame or aluminum extrusion).
Pedal assembly platform (CNC-cut plywood or aluminum base).
Monitor stand or VR setup mount.
software_development: Python or C++ for physics modeling.
CSV/Ts telemetry import pipeline for model calibration.
considerations: Ergonomic driver seating position matching the real car.
Durability of wheelbase and pedal hardware under high load.

5_mounting_and_implementation_on_car.note: The simulator is external and does not mount on the car, but must be calibrated using car data.
implementation_links: Suspension geometry → steering rack ratio in simulator.
Tire model → real telemetry (lateral accel, slip).
Brake system → deceleration vs brake pressure mapping.
Powertrain model → torque map matching real vehicle behavior.
sync_requirements: Use CAN data to match steering angle, wheel speeds, IMU behavior.
Validate simulation behavior with real skidpad and slalom tests.

validation_process: Compare simulated lap times with real lap times for the same driver.
Record braking distance in both sim and real car, adjust model accordingly.
Measure steering corrections per second (CPS) in real vs sim runs.
Test drivers on slalom sections: aim for reduction in cone hits over time.
Evaluate consistency: variance in lap times before vs after simulator usage.
extension: Develop RL-based torque/braking map that can be tested in real-world cones tests.
Integrate telemetry live-stream from real car into simulator for real-time replay mode.

risks: Simulator must be accurate; low realism could mis-train drivers.
Avoid overreliance on sim without validating with real track testing.
opportunities: Can be used for team recruitment events to attract new drivers.
Can be extended into an autonomous-driving research platform.
Possibility of sponsor branding and demo during events.
maintenance: Regular recalibration with fresh telemetry each season.
Review driver analytics monthly to update training schedules.
